content: The Act is titled the "Four Corners Interpretive Center Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purposes section. The Four Corners Monument is significant as the only location in the US where 4 state boundaries meet: Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, and Utah. Boundary lines were drawn between 1868 and 1875, with a monument erected in 1899. A postal stamp was issued in 1999 to mark the centennial. The area has historical, cultural, and prehistoric value, attracting around 250,000 visitors annually despite lacking permanent facilities. The Four Corners Monument Tribal Park falls within Navajo Nation and Ute Mountain Ute Tribe reservations. A memorandum of understanding governs its development. The Four Corners Heritage Council was established in 1992. Arizona has allocated funds for planning and construction. Studies show support for development at the site. Indians support development at the Four Corners Monument Tribal Park for the benefit of the Navajo Nation and Ute Mountain Ute Tribe. The Arizona Department of Transportation has cost estimates for an interpretive center and surrounding infrastructure. The center would offer educational opportunities for all Americans, requiring federal assistance for construction. The Act aims to recognize the importance of the Four Corners Monument. The Four Corners Monument and surrounding landscape are recognized as a distinct area in the heritage of the United States, worthy of interpretation and preservation. The goal is to assist the Navajo Nation and Ute Mountain Ute Tribe in establishing an Interpretive Center and related facilities for the public, showcasing collaborative resource stewardship, and promoting knowledge of the culturally diverse groups in the region. The curr_chunk is a section titled "SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS." In this Act, the term "Center" refers to the Four Corners Interpretive Center with various visitor facilities. "Eligible entity" includes the States of Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, or Utah. The "Four Corners Heritage Council" is a nonprofit coalition established in 1992 by agreements of the Governors of these states. The "Four Corners Monument" is where the boundaries of these states meet. The Four Corners Monument Tribal Park encompasses lands where Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, and Utah meet. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 4. FOUR CORNERS INTERPRETIVE CENTER. The Secretary is authorized to establish the "Four Corners Interpretive Center" within the Four Corners Monument Tribal Park. Land for the Center will be designated by the Navajo Nation or the Ute Mountain Ute Tribe in consultation with the Four Corners Heritage Council and in accordance with relevant agreements. The "Four Corners Interpretive Center" will include permanent and temporary exhibits showcasing the region's heritage, public education programs, preservation efforts for archaeological sites, information on cultural and natural resources, and visitor amenities. The establishment of the center requires consent from the Navajo Nation and the Ute Mountain Ute Tribe. The "Four Corners Interpretive Center" will include exhibits on the region's heritage, education programs, preservation efforts, and visitor amenities. Consent from the Navajo Nation and Ute Mountain Ute Tribe is required for its establishment. The Secretary can award a grant to cover up to 50% of the construction costs for the Center, with the condition that the non-Federal share is paid from various sources including States, private entities, Navajo Nation, and Ute Mountain Ute Tribe. The States must contribute a minimum of $2,000,000 towards the project. The eligible entity selected for the grant must submit a proposal meeting all relevant laws and requirements, with each state contributing at least $2,000,000 in cash or in kind. States can use private funds to meet the grant requirements. Arizona can apply $45,000 for planning and $250,000 for construction from its reserves towards the project. The eligible entity selected for the grant must enter into a memorandum of understanding with the Secretary, providing a timetable for construction, competitive contracts, compliance with building codes, operations and maintenance plans, exhibit design, and security measures for collections. The eligible entity selected for the grant must enter into a memorandum of understanding with the Secretary, providing a timetable for construction, competitive contracts, compliance with building codes, operations and maintenance plans, exhibit design, and security measures for collections. Additionally, the agreement with the Navajo Nation and the Ute Mountain Ute Tribe includes site selection and public access to the facilities, along with a financing plan outlining long-term management of the Center, including funding sources, operating costs coverage, and achieving financial self-sufficiency within 5 years. The eligible entity selected for the grant must achieve financial self-sufficiency within 5 years after the enactment of this Act, and maintain appropriate vendor standards and business activities at the Four Corners Monument Tribal Park. The Four Corners Heritage Council may recommend grant proposals for facility design at the Four Corners Monument Tribal Park to the Secretary. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations for the Department of the Interior to carry out the Act includes $2,000,000 for fiscal year 2000 and $50,000 for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2005. Unexpended funds from 2000 may be used until 2002. The Secretary can reserve funds until a grant proposal meeting the Act's requirements is submitted by September 30, 2001. The Secretary is allowed to accept donations for the planning, construction, and operation of the Center from private or public entities. The Act does not affect any rights or claims of the Navajo Nation or the Ute Mountain Ute Tribe based on existing laws.
